name: transistor production, auxilliaries and energy use | transistor, auxilliaries and energy use | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2013/documentation

This dataset represents the average production efforts of 1 kg of transistors over all types of transistors. There is no distinction between the different types of transisitors produced. Data for auxillaries, energy, emissions and waste are taken from a dataset out of an international LCI database. Infrastructure efforts are based on own assumptions. As the raw material input is taken into account in the respective transistor datasets this dataset here has no input of raw materials. 

From reception of electronic components, raw materials and auxiliares at the factory gate.

This module includes auxillary and energy consumption, emissions (air, water) and waste amounts, as well as an estimation of the efforts for transportation and of the infrastructure for the production of transistors.
category: C:Manufacturing/26:Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products/261:Manufacture of electronic components and boards/2610:Manufacture of electronic components and boards

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data from literature – here representing the global situation.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: average production technology comprising Si-crystal die bonding; wire bonding; encapsulation; plating; triming; forming and marking.;Besides the use of millions of individual or discrete transistors, the vast majority of transistors are fabricated into integrated circuits today  together with diodes, resistors, capacitors and other electronic components in order to establish a complete electronic circuit.

exchanges.description:
A transistor “is a semiconductor device, the most common type of which acts as a current amplifier. There do however exist less common types of transistor - FETs (field effect transistors) - which act as voltage controlled resistors.”
Hence a transistor is a fundamental building block of all the circuitries that govern the operation of computers, cellular phones, and all other modern electronics. Due to their fast response and accuracy, a transistor may be used in a wide variety of digital and analogue functions, including amplification, switching, voltage regulation, signal modulation, and oscillators. Transistors may be packaged individually or as part of an integrated circuit chip, which may hold thousands of transistors in a very small area. 
Low cost, flexibility and reliability have made out of transistors a universal device for non-mechanical tasks, such as digital computing. Transistorized circuits have replaced electromechanical devices for the control of appliances and machinery as well. It is often less expensive and more effective to use a standard microcontroller and write a computer program to carry out a control function than to design an equivalent mechanical control function (Wikipedia, 2007).
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
